text: Since moving to a foreign country, I have developed social anxiety. However, in my home country it is not so bad and the feeling of having to leave work behind is often overwhelming.
It's common for me to refuse to venture out in cities and dislike crowded environments. I also have a strong distaste for people from urban settings, as well as school friends and family.
When should I start swimming? I'm worried about being compelled to swim in the same lane as others and avoid awkward eye contact.
I feel like every time I do something in a public place, it feels as though someone is either watching me doing it and thinking negatively about me or constantly being harshly spoken to by others.

A few years ago, I had the majority of my spine fused. However, due to high risk of type 2 diabetes in my family and fear of public attention from others, it's difficult to run and I despise every minute of running.

One of my friends commented on how I walk like a corpse, with arms hugged to my sides and not swinging. It's frustrating that at 22 I still can't walk normally, which is becoming increasingly difficult due to social anxiety caused by feeling skinny.
Being confined to my home with only my boyfriend and me feeling scared can cause me to leave, even though I know I won't make it through the interview process or end up being fired.

Even if I'm being paid to do a job for someone else, I tend to have premonitions about how I should handle the situation or risk being laughed at. However, when I force myself to go outside more often, it doesn't seem like such dreadful behavior.
Having the option of running is something I would happily do, but my fear of social interactions is too much for me. However, I have enjoyed drinking 8 cups or tea that has brought me peace.
The feeling of discomfort when around someone my age, even if they are highly engaged in their social lives, can make me anxious.

My anxiety and ominousness towards others intensify. The only occasions when I feel more relaxed are when my room is locked away and I am not required to interact with anyone, and whenever I step outside, I cannot seem to be calm enough to behave like an adult.

Without a friend, I experience self-consciousness and anxiety when walking in public without one. This causes me to move quickly and avoid busy streets, even though I'm not sure if this is due to social anxiety or my introversion. The main fear that I face when out in the open is whether others will recognize me as an impatient person who may be uncomfortable with being seen by someone I know, regardless of their location or level of emotional distress.

I've been friends with some online for more than a year, and while I was once in touch with them over the phone, I now find it difficult to communicate with my significant other. This has only improved recently as I often pretend that I can't speak at all and prefer typing. Additionally, there have been several occasions where I loathed being outside, including when my sister told me not to go out; others were due to my mum forcing me to leave behind.

I still walked away from the place every day, even after five years. I thought I heard someone talking and put on my fake facial expression to look like someone was watching me. This happened even though I graduated from high school five year ago and now struggle to walk in places with ease.

My insecurities revolve around my struggles with abandonment, social anxiety, language barrier, dependence on my partner, loneliness and compulsion to step out of my comfort zone, depression symptoms, and the need to cope with rejection.

Being out of sight as soon possible was a huge lift for me. I'm still at university and feeling great, but the weight loss has been remarkable. Although I am not skinny, I have achieved similar results (I also run like other young men), it is difficult to feel isolated in my room.

It is dangerous to engage in SA while participating in parkour or other extreme sports. I have fallen twice in the past two months, the first time when I suffered a sprained ankle (I grade), and didn't realize it was just luck. However after discovering this later, I am now suffering from mild social anxiety.
Despite my efforts, finding work is no longer possible as I feel unworthy of it and struggle to communicate with others.

I'm constantly being stopped by people I know from high school, but my dad believes it's a foolish idea. I haven't joined the military even though I want to join, and I suffer from knee replacement tendonitis due to long-distance running. Although I feel like an outsider, I can' not trust anyone who has ever seen me in action or improved their quality of life.

A 6'5" tall guy would be extremely uncomfortable sitting alone in a park. My therapy therapist is suggesting me to try walking around the park and chilling, but I fear that people might find it creepy.
If I were to go out and meet other kids, I wouldn't have any interesting stories or talk about them. Despite my blackness, discussing U1tikal's identity and videos on YouTube would be tedious.

I am also dealing with anxiety when interacting with my family members and will suffer from vomiting whenever I go out. I experience frequent bouts of nausea, mental anguish, and up to 90% of cases vomit during my time outdoors.

Despite being 21 and living with my parents, I haven't left my home in months. Although it made me feel more comfortable, there are some things that diet and exercise can' not fix... such as my face, which is extremely unattractive. It's just a vicious cycle that keeps me stuck indoors for longer periods of time, making the outside world too intimidating.
I have high hopes for swimming, but my low self-esteem and anxiety are making it difficult for me to enjoy the outdoors. Can you suggest ways that I can overcome these challenges?

My inability to penetrate more deeply is preventing me from making any progress. Instead, I've been doing my usual routine of not going out for two months and only leaving when someone tries to take me by the arm. This has given me a sense of hope.
My medication has helped me feel better, but I still have to go potty when someone asks about my puppy. What steps have you taken to alleviate this?
While outside, I find myself surrounded by people either smoking or watching the pit. It's too uncomfortable for me to simply relax and enjoy this moment due to my newfound sense of self.
"I'm feeling drained, frustrated, and unmotivated because my brain is so engaged in daily activities that I can't even think of finishing something."

Does playing soccer by myself seem unusual given that I have to attend a test for my maths class and don't like running. However, there is hardly anyone around who can help me get in shape for the big game.

The thought of going to class has become unbearable to me, especially since I can't brave the pain of walking past others. It's only been two weeks since my last lesson, and I'm feeling really uncomfortable about missing every class because it makes me feel even more afraid to go to the next one.
The act of walking around with people laughing makes me anxious about their laughter, as I thought it was silly. However, these thoughts have become more intrusive in recent times.

Every day, I have to take my two dogs for walks in my neighborhood, which is a source of misery. This has been affecting me for the past two years as I struggle to maintain my social standing and am thought to be untrustworthy even on bad days.

The constant presence of drivers on the roads makes me anxious about walking outside. As a result, I have to walk to school every morning. While it would be nice to go for walks with other people on sidewalks, as is the case in New York, living in the suburbs where there are no one but errant individuals and cars are constantly glancing at me.

My problems were not there until now, but they began to arise when I had a hard time maintaining eye contact with others, developing egotistical tendencies, feeling uncomfortable around myself and wanting approval, being self-conscious in public, entering crowded places, and feeling anxious while driving.

Due to my lack of social connections in the city, I am hesitant to venture out alone. I simply needed someone to express my feelings and address any concerns. The new job has left me feeling unwelcome due to the unfriendly nature of the people at my workplace.

Outside of school, I experienced no issues despite any verbal or nonverbal abuse. However, my classmates were not worried about leaving, and I was unable to joke around or make fun of others' faces. I didn't communicate with anyone outside my class, which left me feeling isolated and people around me thinking that I looked like an idiot.

I miss the days when I felt almost euphoric just sitting outside my computer for the entire day. The same goes for those long hours spent in front of my PC, and the dopamine my brain gave me after being worn out from cycling with friends all day long, leaving me able to rest while playing video games.
It is said that I should feel better after doing this enough times, but since I've been going out regularly, I still experience negative emotions every day. Hence, my questioning myself.

Despite applying for retail jobs, my depressed state has continued. I am currently waiting for a call from someone who is aware of my skills and experience. My country's hiring authorities seem to favor experienced candidates, but since I have been out alone most of the time, they assume I may be unqualified to work there.
It's common to feel anxious when I'm doing certain activities, but I tend to make time for them. Despite this, my anxiety is not as intense as it might seem.

As a 3-year college student, I find myself going to classes in class but never talking to anyone during the day before returning to my dorm room for school and watching movies. I'm feeling depressed because I feel like being alone all the time, which makes me feel sad sometimes.
My lack of friends makes me feel depressed, especially since I avoid speaking to strangers in my backyard.

Even though I'm on the path to recovery in California, my social anxiety is still a concern. While it's not impossible for me to be positive, I can't help but feel anxious and frustrated when I cross over from the Golden Gate Bridge, House of Full House, or Goldengate Park.

The way I walk makes me feel self-conscious. During our walks, cars are passing by and my partner becomes angry when I appear stiff or awkward. However, I have thoughts of how people will judge my walking style until I step out of my comfort zone.

After being invited to a barbecue two weeks ago, I have been experiencing anxiety due to my unusual feet (strangely white) and severe scholiosis. The main reason is that I am afraid of people who may try to swim with me in the pool as I own large complexes.

In a span of four weeks, what are some ways I can overcome these obstacles that have arisen over the last year? Although I'm no longer in high school and feel like an outcast, my self-esteem is struggling to cope with the negative attention towards me on social media.

It's a common occurrence for me to feel extremely anxious and scared when I leave my house for work, leading me down the train platform and into an empty station. Does anyone else experience feelings of safety and happiness while hiding?
Anyone who's been ridiculed for being "skinny," "youthful," or "repulsive" can feel very uncomfortable when confronted with this situation.

Drivers, I haven't really learned how to drive - I practiced just about every reversing in my life. In the morning when it's too early and I made one run down a busy road before going inside. Today, during the day, this is what I drove on that side of the road.
Despite my interest in going out, I'm not entirely sure why I feel this way. Could it be because I have a preference for staying at home and being more comfortable with exercise?

I am unable to water my garden due to the presence of my neighboring residents who are constantly looking at it. This situation has become increasingly challenging as people have been criticizing me for not doing things properly and feeling uncomfortable about following their lead.

While I am experiencing anxiety and depression, I find it difficult to leave the camp because I can't go out. Additionally, my fear of being alone during trips has resulted in me having panic attacks.
Being outside has made me feel anxious and has caused me to feel uneasy. Whenever people look at or drive by me, I experience discomfort.

Feeling judged and criticized by people in other cars during car rides and walks with friends at school made me feel extremely anxious. I never allowed myself to be alone and uncomfortable around others, and it affected my social life even after leaving the house.

My attempts to push myself outside and interact with others are traumatic and unsettling, especially when people don't seem to be fully reconciled. I've worked hard to cope with this through therapy, meditation, medication, and other interventions throughout my junior high school years.

Due to my obesity, I no longer like eating or staying outside as much as before. My friends haven't seen me in 2-3 years, and I had a hard time leaving school when I was 15 due to social anxiety and panic attacks.
Being compelled to go outside of my daily routine and avoid socializing due to fear of being looked down upon, self-conscious, or looking foolish are all I can do.

My preferred places to go out and about are the beaches, cafes, bars, and restaurants. However if I am talking about something that I know, I tend to get shaken and sweaty quickly. In those instances, people stare at me and laugh uncontrollably.

Moreover, my mental state becomes so abnormal that I feel like an inept goth outside and have the ability to see beyond myself. This leads me to experience insane levels of social anxiety, which I experienced as a teenager but didn't fully heal.
Because of my severe online anxiety, I am unable to leave my home after leaving high school at 16 and have been staying with my mother ever since.

My parents' house has been a source of anxiety for me since I moved there 20 years ago. Although I have few neighbors, the fact that it's in populated streets makes my identity uncertain. I couldn't help but feel like I was missing something when someone pulled up my windshield wipers and I noticed some honking outside.
My current situation involves being homeless and living with my grandmother, but I need to find a temporary job that will help me earn money as I have limited time outside of education.

When I was on medication, I would wake up feeling a sense of anxiety and avoid socializing with others due to my constant thoughts of being alone. Although it didn't completely cure me entirely, it made the experience more bearable.

Am about to stand up after sitting on the grass with a group of people. I'm not too worried about standing up when there's only 2 metres between me and the rest of the group. Even in public situations where my movements are awkward or uncomfortable, such as when someone is sitting beside me, makes me feel uneasy.

Coming from a young age and having experienced it since childhood, I understand the exhausting feeling of leaving home and experiencing fear before engaging in simple activities. This is why I created this subreddit, as social anxiety is one of the most severe mental illnesses.

Despite wearing clothes, makeup, and trying to be kind, I feel uncomfortable going out. My voice is not very good, as I have undergone plastic surgery and laser hair removal for $20,000 alone. This has resulted in me looking terrible with my facial hair, which doesn't seem so natural anymore.
It's causing me to experience severe anxiety and head tremors when I leave my home, even though I can usually go to the supermarket or other places without difficulty.

Can anyone suggest strategies for finding social connections in real life while dealing with social anxiety? I find it difficult to make new friends when surrounded by many people, and often feel like I don't have the time or energy to do so alone.

For the past decade, my preference for summer has been influenced by social anxiety, which has resulted in increased exposure to heat, sweat, and less clothing. As a fat person, this can make wearing clothes uncomfortable and expose me to sweaty clothing that comes with summer wear.

At 20 years old, I have never had a job and was dropped from 10th grade due to constant bullying. My feelings towards myself have become intense and I am afraid of being judged by others who may judge me in public.
My personal experience is that I am not able to wear short clothes in public and I feel like I look like Phoebe from Friends. The gym is always packed, which means I avoid it altogether.

I don't see people often enough to suggest we meet, but I prefer a bike ride with fewer people on the route. I'm uncertain about whether or not to tell them I feel nervous about going out in public without any warning as it makes me an anxious person.
My anxiety and fear of missing out on social events can be overwhelming, as I feel like I'm going crazy for the pool party without my friends.

The man greets my mother and me before joining my friend and brother who are both in the same room. I couldn't help but run back upstairs to my bedroom and put on my basketball jersey and shorts while my friends were talking to strangers. They pointed out our names, prompting her to suggest a game for us all to watch at the doctor.

My 18th birthday is coming up in a few days, and I'm starting to feel anxious about everything, including going out with friends or taking the bus. This has been getting worse since last summer, as I haven't been feeling better yet. Even my best friend was worried and told about it before I went away.
In the past, I have been exposed to bullying and humiliation wherever I went outside as a teenager. Now that I'm back in school, it's making me feel like being outside is something worth doing again.
Joining a soccer club has me feeling scared and uneasy, as I fear that I may be joining an unfamiliar group of people who have already made their friends.

As a 19-year-old who has not exercised much in the past and has never been involved in sports, I feel like I should go for jogging in my morning. However, this doesn't change the fact that I don'T want to be defined by my appearance but rather aim to become fit and toned.

The inability to walk is due to the fact that I can see people staring at me from their cars as they cross an intersection. I feel like everyone is judging me, even though I am walking and there are other individuals watching me closely.
Even though I enjoy doing various yoga poses and handstands, I feel uncomfortable doing them in public due to the presence of people who may be expressing different opinions.
It's my third day of swimming and I'm feeling nervous about the upcoming swim.

After 3 months, I stopped leaving the house unless I had an appointment. This is after being told that I don't feel comfortable outside and it's getting harder every day. I often say awkward things during conversations and feel like people are judging me.

My psychologist visits are expensive and I have only done it 7 times. Then I went to a psychiatric clinic, which was essentially putting me through three diagnoses before having any meaningful treatment.
Like you, I have a fondness for running, but the fear of passing by someone else or people waving in front of me is my biggest weakness. Running makes me feel so vulnerable and uncomfortable.
Whenever I miss a train, I quit running and don't run even though it's not common.

Despite having shared it several times in the past, I find it uncomfortable to run and walk at a slower pace. Any extra attention or criticism from others is unappealing; however, it's not beneficial for me. This can be attributed to my previous running routine in early mornings, which was cut short due to social anxiety.
The most frightening part is going into a store in the middle of... [market] and walking down that aisle.

Social anxiety has left me feeling like I'm too comfortable with my own body, which makes it difficult for me to communicate effectively with other people. Since then, we've had occasional conflicts where they seem to revolve around what I should be like, such as wearing well-known clothes and being considered good-looking or having good manners.

This list is a bit of nonsense but it's quite comprehensive. I've been doing great at school, have friends who are supportive, enjoyed my hobbies, and tried to help others when I was feeling down. My life has been mostly focused on other areas- socializing, dating, love (including food), family relationships, positive self-esteem among relatives, etc.

Since moving here, I am not familiar with the area. I've been thinking about walking outside in public, but being alone is terrifying to me. Normally, we go out together for medical visits, and it's difficult to see anyone who takes care of us on a regular basis without their help.

My doctor advised me to swim as it might alleviate my back pain, but I don't have a perfect body. Additionally; walking around with strangers who are more attractive than mine is incredibly scary. As for us, we are all human beings and not like animals that look like lonesome humans.
It seems like people are constantly mocking or peeing me when I'm gazing into their eyes, especially when they have caught me in the act.

It's my usual routine, but I feel a sense of regret for not doing it. While I would be willing to go to the pool like everyone else, I always end up getting people'd off with their kind expressions. Thank you for your help!
I experienced this. Meeting people who are my age is a common source of fear when traveling abroad.

If you pass someone, it's acceptable to look around and be close. I also feel apprehensive about walking by them at night. To minimize the chance of seeing people in public, I prefer to avoid eye contact.

Walking outside has always been a part of my life since I was able to walk like. A lot of people think that I am less vulnerable because more people will see me than they would otherwise, but when I sit down there is definitely the hardest part and I feel more at ease being there.

It's a subjective matter since SAD affects people differently, and I was constantly worried that others were watching me and judging me. If someone has difficulty with basic interactions and avoids socializing, it could indicate they have some form of SADD or another mental disorder.
I cannot bike in public without feeling like everyone is staring at me. I don't want to inconvenience anyone. It's a horror to throw an obstacle course with an unknown person.

Despite my lack of speed, I experience feelings of inadequacy when walking correctly. When I am with others and feel uneasy about being observed or judged by others, this is why I despise leaving the premises due to these emotions.
Despite my desire to spend time with others, I am constantly plagued by fear and anxiety.

Despite having to go outside for 30 minutes, the noise from my apartment and other people making eye contact is unbearable. I'm worried about what might happen when someone tells me they're sick of being picked up by the cashier who may have bought things for me in Target or WalMart.

The idea of going outside doesn't appeal to me, even if I feel anxious and paranoid. On the other hand, I find it relaxing and comforting when I walk in rainy conditions at 3am. Group therapy or face-to-face meetings with health professionals can help alleviate these symptoms.
Even though I'm 21, I still don't feel at ease in a park, and I feel too old for the latter.

After a while, I still don't feel comfortable with running. However, after completing 1-2 hours of it in stretches or walks, my anxiety doesn's disappear. In other situations, such as leaving my apartment for the first time and walking along the paths until reaching the beach, this can be uncomfortable but not unbearable.

I was struggling with agoraphobia during my last year of university and it has become a regular issue. It's been difficult to see progress like this, especially when I have to travel out of the house for medication on recurring days.

Despite my love for the outdoors, I am constantly nervous when it comes to going out and finding parking spots. It is common for men to ask for money or other necessities from me, even if they don't have any cash.

I never reveal my true identity and always avoid going out to shops, restaurants or parks to stay away from people. Despite not having been diagnosed, I find it difficult to engage in activities like walking with my dog. It's believed that this is a result of social anxiety caused by bullying in school. Since moving into the 21st century, these difficulties have intensified.

At the age of 12-16, I suffered from severe social anxiety that made me fear leaving my house or speaking to only close friends and family. Moreover, Agoraphobia is an anxiety disorder that can be caused by various risky situations such as open spaces/public transit/shopping centers...along with frequent trips to parks and other locations where people feel unsafe and have no escape routes. Since then, these experiences have led to frequent panic attacks and intense crying.

A time came when I had to leave and rest on a bench by the pavement, which was almost uncomfortable. Now that I can look back, I feel like smiling after that. In China today, sometimes I used to walk in the opposite direction as there were many Chinese people around me.

Essentially, I lived in the Victorian era during the 1890s and was once overweight. Although I could remove my shirt, at least not as often because I feel unhappy about how I compare to others who are fit, so I have started covering everything up.

Despite being out and about, I'm not fond of going out much. It's just the presence of others around me, which may sound silly but I don't mind being so loud and extrovert with only a few people I know.
Finding the light is possible if you look in the dark.

Even though I experienced anxiety and some strong feelings, they were comprehensible due to being in such busy settings as restaurants or swimming pools. My attempts to avoid meltdowns and panic attacks while in a studio with thirty other people have been unsuccessful.

I roll over and listen to a man shouting at me from the parking lot, "You rollerblades!" He quickly ran me down the street and onto some rocks, almost hitting me with my face. I got up and off again, remove my roller blades, return to my apartment, and proceeded to walk downstairs after 5 minutes of walking around wondering where I was going next.

As a 15-year-old high school student, I am struggling with anxiety and dislike running for 10 seconds. I don't think it would be safe as my mother wouldn'T want me to commit suicide. However, after 9 years of being in the same class, PE is now an option because everyone in my class looks great!

There is hope that things can be better for you, and I have more confidence in you. I'm feeling uneasy about the fact that I don't seem to be able to handle people leaving their cars or homes and trying to talk to me; it may not make me any happier, but there's no shame in my being like this.

My emotions are consumed by the stress of going out, which is ruining my holidays and making me more afraid of the world around me. I don't know if I will be able to cope with this situation as it marks the beginning of our first year at university, and I remember when I struggled with small victories like buying something for the grocery store.

text: My behavior is characterized by insignificant details, such as when talking to someone at work about outdoor activities or the weather. I sometimes act like I enjoy it too, but not so much because I dislike warm weather and prefer playing video games indoors.

My hikes were often accompanied by solitude, but the peace I found during my trip was fleeting and could not be relearned. The first week of my 2.5-week solo backpacking trip in Nepal involved significant isolation, with occasional meals missed to avoid socializing with other backpackers.

I feel uncomfortable when my mom invites me and my family to the beach, citing my lack of social interaction and only spending short amounts of time outside with my loved ones. Instead, it's clear that we don't have much in common.

My love for spending time with my family is limited to just weekends and holidays, making me unable to enjoy life without them. I also lack the desire to go to the beach or engage in recreational activities due to school commitments.

Can I go to the beach without worrying about my safety? I'm considering going, but I know that it's not feasible for me to stay here for more than 3 hours due to my upcoming illness and being alone in the water with no one else around. My fear is making me reconsider this option as my mom works on something else.
I'm weighing my options when it comes to making plans for the weekend. Should I go swimming with my friend on Skype from home, or do I spend more time doing nothing?
Despite my lack of driving experience, I feel uncomfortable in cars with no tinted windows. It's sickening how quickly I can go outside without wearing clothes that feels uncomfortable.

The situation is making me uncertain about what to do, and I'm hoping this sub can provide the necessary assistance. I thought about it for a long time but now realized there might be something more beneficial. One evening, I was invited to supper and felt terrible, leaving me feeling repulsed.

The lack of motivation to play with my child often makes me feel depressed and anxious, as it's difficult to be around other people at home. I've even resorted to playing in the park occasionally, but it doesn't help that fact.

I went on AN exchange for Japanese language but after two weeks of sickness I felt remorseful about returning. On Men's Day, there were occasions when I celebrated with them, but I also felt isolated and emotional.

I make an effort to expand my knowledge through various activities, but the results are often disappointing. For instance, after trying out for a rowing team, I was ignored and now have the worst performance.

I was used to feeling insecure for a period and eventually changed my routine by running errands. However, now that I have adjusted from having kids to being more active with exercise, it feels like an entirely different experience than myself.

There's a part of me that wants to brace myself and be there for her, but I'm not well-versed in social interactions. My boyfriend proposed, so we decided to stay together over the weekend, except for him. But now my plans have changed, and I can't join anyone else.
Can anyone relate to my feeling of being alone and sad even when I'm spending time on the beach? It's becoming a problem every year, as I can't go out without someone to spend time with.

The fact that my mom used to take me on sports like soccer and tennis has never troubled me. However, as I have grown older with time, the fear of having no chance in starting a new sport made me reconsider.
I often feel like I walk unnaturally, have a disconcerting figurehead and am discouraged by the constant self-doubt.
Although I would like to go outside, my anxiety causes me to feel completely isolated, even when walking on my own. I might start walking in the morning when there are few people out with me.

With a socially unstable temperament and autism spectrum disorder, I have never been outside alone as an adult. Additionally, my lack of friends and companionship has left me fearful of being bullied or harassed by society.

My studies at an overseas university were cut short when I left, having been in a harmful relationship with someone who had narcissistic tendencies. After two years of being away, I returned home to find myself feeling depressed and have no hope of returning for another year or living independently.
Could there be any way for someone to start a conversation with me after seeing the book I'm reading? I find it odd that they prefer not to spend time together in parks.

Despite the appeal of lounging in parks, there might be some interference from someone trying to disturb me or from playing too loud music. I enjoy their company but never know for sure. My walks with friends and family at night also seem to stir up suspicions. Can you confirm this?

Whenever I walk outside, I feel terrified and people look at me like I'm socially inferior. I once experienced this behavior while walking next to a car that was constantly in my vicinity. The people inside were too busy to deal with me.

I could apply for any job I desired without worrying about missing an interview because of my fear of not answering the phone and getting back to my boss. I would be able to visit every corner of the city, feel comfortable in comfort, and socialize with friends.

I'm not experiencing any significant changes in my emotions and therefore, my perspective on socializing is still unsatisfactory. I feel like I need to wait until I can finally move beyond the stage of being socially adolescent and find some purpose in life. Who would want to meet someone with depression?
I tried explaining to her how I want to be more organized and spend time outside. However, when it comes down to doing things outside, I feel like quitting and feeling a sense of calmness.

As someone who has struggled with social anxiety for the past decade, I now find myself struggling with similar issues to those I face when running at night. Although I enjoy my passion for running, it makes me feel less self-aware and gives up on the task of exercising in public.

The combination of anxiety and stress has been a major issue for me, as I am struggling to balance my day with the demands of everyday life. My weight is low, and I find myself losing more than usual due to eating and feeling anxious.

I get nervous around people I'm unfamiliar with and anxious about going out with friends or family. I try not to engage in social situations by simply looking at the ground, and struggle to maintain eye contact even if my mom or dad is talking to me.
For hours on end, I constantly wonder what could have possibly gone wrong when I need to go out. This often leads me to evade going out during the day or in the evening.
My favorite way to walk is my parents' house, but I despise going out because I always feel like I'm being stalked by cars. I choose car travel instead.
Despite having used Uber before, I'm now 18 and considering using a vape to relieve nerve pain.
After breaking up with my boyfriend, I experienced a sudden panic attack while giving smooches and running from class.
The activity of walking around my neighborhood and being alone is something I absolutely hate. I also feel uncomfortable when I'm alone and others are staring at me.

Even with minimal noise, I feel like someone is peeping through their windows or at a certain point in time. I can't help but cry and worry about being judged by my parents who may have noticed me and recognized others from my high school even though I graduated two years ago.

I have a strong affinity for both sunnier days and dark nights, but my fear of being alone at the beach during vacation time makes it difficult to enjoy them without feeling lonely. On the other hand, if we are experiencing snow on winter, having fewer cold nights is even more enjoyable due to the peace one craves.
